conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their position and size depend on the light source's position relative to the object.
In the first image, the light source is positioned such that shadows are cast to the left of the objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are formed by the respective objects above them.
The light source moves to the right, changing the angle at which light hits the objects.
When the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left due to the change in light angle.
The size of the shadows will change based on the distance and angle of the light source relative to the objects.
If the light source moves closer to the objects, the shadows will become larger and more elongated.
If the light source moves further away, the shadows will become smaller and more compact.
In the second image, the shadows have shifted to the left, confirming the change in position due to the movement of the light source.
The size of the shadows appears to have changed slightly, indicating a change in the distance or angle of the light source.
When the light source moves to the right above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift to the left.
The size of the shadows may increase or decrease depending on the distance and angle of the light source relative to the objects.
